bookmarks.note: Example labels, based on any accusations the counterpart might make (remember, it’s you and the “adversary” vs. the situation. They are with you against the negotiation, you’re not against them). Make up to 5 labels per each anticipated accusation they might make. The labels are designed to elicit more information from them
Reread: what did he do instead of asking why? I think he used a label?

Reread the end of each chapter. The book breaks down the most important points as bullet points there

“Would you like to join our frequent buyer program?”
“Do I get a discount for joining?”
“No.”
Friendly: “My name is Chris. What’s the Chris discount?”

How to get people to say yes three times: first they say yes, then you label or summarize what they said so they answer “that’s right.” And #3 is a calibrated how/what question about implementation that asks them to explain success
It hit the news (and common citizens know about it) means we care

If you have to throw put the first offer, go with an anchor (high/low to plant a eg higher idea (in the case of a salary) in their mind, and range (instead of a number), in order to bend their reality)
IMPORTANT: how to anchor before providing bad news
That’s right signals that negotiations can proceed from deadlock
Paraphrasing + labeling = summary. A good summary always yields a “That’s right”
Paraphrasing + labeling = summary. A good summary always yields a “That’s right”
Paraphrasing is also important when mirroring
Label, tactical empathy, label. And, only then, a request
Label emotions. This will make it so my brain responds rationally, instead of activating the amygdala (UCLA Matthew Lieberman)

How to deal with someone who wants consent:
1. Use the “late-night, FM DJ” voice
2. Start with, “I’m sorry”
3. Mirror
4. Silence (at least 4 seconds to let the mirror work)
5. Repeat

If you’re mirroring someone else (as a negotiation technique), you shouldn’t ask extra questions if they don’t want you to know something. Or else they’ll lie, and you lose all the rapport you’ve built
Negotiation approach used to be half-MSU (making shit up) and half sales approach (persuade, coerce, or manipulate in any way possible)
Playing different games... like in chess
